text: I'm Matt gross the frugal traveler for
the new york times this summer I'm
embarking on the grand tour of Europe
over 12 weeks I'll seek out ancient
history and contemporary culture I'll
find cool hotels and eat memorable meals
and I'll stretch the US dollar to the
breaking point from up here edinborough
looks like such a nice peaceful city so
medieval so stately so stoic a relaxing
place to spend the final week of my
frugal grand tour of Europe what fight
fight fight fight fight shut down in the
streets the Scottish capital isn't a
friendly it's August and burn has been
taken over by the fringe festival of
comedy theater dance music and whatever
else you can think of there more than
2,000 shows playing so it can be tricky
to figure out what's worth seeing and
what's not one way to narrow down your
option and the save life is simply to
watch the free performances that are
going on all over the city some of them
are quite good like these Japanese mind
oh
others well sometimes you get what you

unpredictable weather if you happen to

can get quick previews of lots of lots
of chips
he's lying again please mind the gap

show
something for expression well not

actually the easiest way to pick which

to ask the people who are out there in
the streets promoting their work so a
surrealist heist thriller it's a parody

American accent what's a really good fun

shackled moon they're small it's about
male infertility essentially set in Iraq
with blood guts guns gore prostitutes
pimps and talking sheep and there you
have it the Edinburgh Fringe dusty
frankly after a few days of crazy
theater and constant downpours I had a
serious case of Fringe fatigue but in
Edinburgh relief lies minutes away on
the fringes of town in the crags and
peaks of Holyrood park this is going up
to arthur's seat one of the crags that
overlooks the city of edinburgh after
three months of constant adventure the
grand tour is over and I have to say I'm
a little worn out but I also know that
as soon as i'm home as soon as i look at
these images as soon as i remember the
foods I've eaten and the friends I've
made I'll be craving the open road again
this grant or may be over but only for
the moment for the New York Times this
is matt gross the frugal traveler
